title: Eat PUTAV
historical_context: This article discusses methods to bypass registration checks in software, particularly focusing on PKZIP, a popular file compression utility of the time. It reflects the hacker culture's interest in software reverse engineering and serial number cracking.
target_audience: Hackers, security researchers, software developers interested in reverse engineering.
short_summary: The article explores methods to bypass PKZIP's registration checks using brute force techniques and memory manipulation. It details the use of distributed processing to speed up the cracking process and introduces alternative methods for generating valid registration strings.
summary:
In 'Eat PUTAV', Demogorgon details the process of cracking PKZIP registration serial numbers, highlighting the evolution from the slow brute-force method of 'makeav' to the more efficient 'findav'. The article describes how Dark Angel modified 'findav' to log every valid serial number found, allowing for a comprehensive search for McAfee's registration numbers. The author recounts an experiment where they utilized twenty 80386 systems at a university to distribute the workload, significantly speeding up the cracking process. This illustrates the early use of distributed computing in hacking efforts.

Additionally, the article presents an alternative method to manipulate the validation string generated by PKZIP. By using backspace characters in the registration name, hackers can overwrite the validation string with their own. This technique emphasizes the creativity and resourcefulness of hackers in finding ways to bypass software protections. Overall, the article serves as a historical snapshot of the hacking techniques prevalent in the early 1990s, showcasing the blend of technical skill and collaborative effort in the hacker community.
